Russell Gold wrote:

>  > Absolutely, Russell. I just want that manager to SAY IT. To me, that's
>  > important. I won't be complicit in an unspoken scheme to go slower,
>  > because at the end of the day, when we don't go fast enough, the
>  > executives will rain on the managers will rain on me. No thanks.
> 
> Ah, but it's not the reasonable first level manager who says it. It's
> the VP of the organization, who has given up trying to buck the
> standards officers. And they don't believe that my procedure will
> help, but they are certain that the standard they worked so hard to
> put into place solved a lot of problems for them - and have seen chaos
> ensue with programmers spitting out chicken heads all over the
> place...
> 
> Large organizations tend to lack the immediacy of accountability which
> facilitates progress.

Presumably I can get the VP's phone number....

>  > PROGRAMMER: "As long as we're clear that the corporate standard is more
>  > important than how productive I can be as a programmer, I'm fine with
>  > that. By the way, I won't be working any unpaid overtime this year.
>  > Sorry about that."
> 
> Easier to say when unemployment is low :)

Don't blame it on the employment rate; blame it on personal financial 
planning. I left IBM in November 2001, and virtually everyone I tell 
that asks, "How did you survive?" It's simple, really: I planned.
--
